docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of the year, 364 workers at Mueller's noodle factory in Jersey City will be grappling with a problem as common as it is traumatic. The factory is moving to Columbia, S.C., where labor is cheaper and unions are rare. Workers here will be laid off. To get another good job, they will probably have to go back to school. People in their 40's and 50's, people who have bought houses and supported children with good union wages, must face the job interviewers as shaky, inexperienced novices, competing with young people fresh out of college. Over the past 30 years, some 500,000 New Jersey workers have lived this story, the story of the disappearance of blue-collar union manufacturing jobs and with them, the security and prosperity of a huge class of Americans. Camden ship-builders, Paterson garment-workers and Mercer County spacecraft manufacturers -- all know the story well.

headline.main: Retraining for a Job, But What Kind of a Job?

docs.abstract: New Jersey Employment and Training Commission says some 4,000 laid-off workers in state are currently training for new careers; say most will study for less than year, and 70 percent will land new jobs; labor leaders, who question usefulness of job-training, agree with state job-training administrators that new jobs will almost certainly pay less; current unemployment rate in New Jersey is 5.5 percent; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE chance to purchase a home with a maximum down payment of $2,500 will be one of the attractions of a home-buyers' fair on May 10 at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale. The fair will be sponsored by the New York office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. The offer comes in the form of a certificate available only at the fair and only to a buyer who agrees to purchase a home with a Government-insured F.H.A mortgage and to occupy that home. Such loans usually require a down payment of 3 to 5 percent of the sales price. Regular mortgages usually require a down payment of at least 10 percent.

headline.main: HUD Fair Offers Low Down Payments on Its Houses

docs.abstract: Home-buyers' fair on May 10 will be sponsored by New York office of Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development; people attending fair will be offered chance to purchase home with maximum down payment of $2,500, if they agree to purchase home with Government-insured FHA mortgage and to occupy that home; photos (In the Region/Long Island) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If buildings could shiver, this Camden, N.J., tenement would have the shakes. It is a February morning too cold for words. The parking lot is a moonscape of craters and ice, and what was once a buzzer is now another crevice for the Arctic wind to exploit. That leaves Kathryn Edin stranded below a kitchen window, announcing her arrival with a shout. She is indefatigably cheerful.
docs.abstract: Jason DeParle profile of Kathryn Edin, unusual poverty expert who does field interviews with welfare mothers; discusses her findings that many families on welfare suffer privations even though most have some unreported income; she notes that women taking entry-level jobs need some family help to be able to work and are even more likely than those on welfare to be unable to pay their bills; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The planned merger of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurance companies in New Jersey and Delaware collapsed this week because the firms could not complete the deal by a May 20 deadline, company executives said yesterday. The two arms of the giant nonprofit health insurer were supposed to have joined forces to create a $3 billion company with more than two million members under an agreement announced last May, but the plan faced legal and regulatory obstacles, said Fred Hillmann, a spokesman for New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Presidential conference on volunteerism that starts tomorrow in Philadelphia does not need to instill a charitable spirit in Americans. They already possess it. Come a catastrophe, like the recent floods in North Dakota, and Americans turn out in droves to place sandbags and help victims. Millions of Americans routinely supervise recess at their local schools or clear trash from their local parks. Over 90 million of them contribute a startling 20 billion hours a year of voluntary service. But the conference's co-chairman, Colin Powell, knows that the quantity of volunteer work is not the only factor. One of his missions is to marshal commitments from Americans, from corporate C.E.O.'s to assembly-line workers, to work with millions of ''at-risk'' youths, many from dysfunctional families. The former general has his sights on the right target.
docs.abstract: Editorial on Presidential conference on volunteerism that starts tomorrow in Philadelphia, and conf co-chmn Colin Powell's call for commitments from Americans, from corporate CEO's to assembly-line workers, to work with millions of 'at-risk' children, many from dysfunctional families

docs.lead_paragraph: The Government said today that the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for elderly people would run out of money in just four years if Congress took no action to slow spending or raise taxes. In their annual report, the Medicare trustees, including three members of President Clinton's Cabinet, said no progress had been made in alleviating the program's severe short- and long-term financial problems.

headline.main: Medicare's Hospital Fund Going Insolvent, Trustees Affirm

docs.abstract: Annual report by Medicare trustees says fund that pays hospital bills for elderly people will run out of money in four years if Congress takes no action to slow spending or raise taxes; reiterates warning made last year; Sec Donna Shalala calls for action (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vesta Insurance Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the two main operating subsidiaries of Anthem Casualty Insurance Group Inc. for $238.8 million. Anthem Casualty, of Shelby, Ohio, sells insurance through about 1,500 independent agents in the Midwest and Middle Atlantic states. Anthem Casualty's business consists mostly of auto and homeowners' insurance sold in small towns and suburbs. Under the deal, Vesta, an insurance holding company based in Birmingham, Ala., will buy the Anthem Casualty Insurance Company and the Shelby Insurance Company, which have a combined $275 million in annualized premiums. Anthem Casualty is owned by Anthem Inc., an Indianapolis-based health management company.

headline.main: VESTA INSURANCE BUYS TWO SUBSIDIARIES FROM ANTHEM

docs.abstract: Vesta Insurance Group Inc agrees to buy main operating subsidiaries of Anthem Casualty Insurance Group Inc--Anthem Casualty Insurance Co and Shelby Insurance Co--for $238.8 million; Anthem Casualty sells insurance through about 1,500 independent agents in Midwest and Middle Atlantic states (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a feat that has raised questions about the uses of medical science, a woman 63 years and 9 months old recently gave birth to a healthy baby girl. Her doctors say that as far as they know, she is the oldest woman ever to give birth. The woman was well past menopause, but she became pregnant by using a donated egg from a much younger woman.

headline.main: A Record and Big Questions As Woman Gives Birth at 63

docs.abstract: Doctors say woman 63 years and 9 months old recently gave birth to healthy baby girl in feat that has raised questions about uses of medical science; say she is oldest woman ever to give birth; say woman was well past menopause, but she became pregnant by using donated egg from younger woman; doctors refuse to identify woman, but say she lives in Los Angeles area and that her baby was delivered by Caesarean section late last year; say she lied about her age because fertility center that assisted her bars women over 55; woman's successful pregnancy and births to other women over age 60 raise questions about whether there should be age limit for pregnancy and, if so, who should decide that woman is too old to bear child (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senators John H. Chafee and John D. Rockefeller 4th said today that they were introducing bipartisan legislation that would expand Medicaid to cover five million additional children. Their approach is distinctly different from that of Senators Orrin G. Hatch and Edward M. Kennedy, who have proposed financing coverage of children by increasing the cigarette tax, a move opposed by the Republican leadership.

headline.main: Senate Bills to Extend Medicaid to Children

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Dole Urges Approval Of Chemical Weapons Ban Bob Dole urged the Senate to approve a treaty banning chemical weapons, which is to come to a vote today. Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, hinted that he was close to supporting the treaty. Their comments were expected to influence several wavering Republicans. A1 Peru Hostages Knew of Raid President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru disclosed details of the raid that led to the spectacular rescue of 71 hostages from the Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima on Tuesday. Underground tunnels were used, and at least some hostages had advance warning of the raid, allowing them to help the Government soldiers get into the compound, he and some of the former hostages said. A1 Many Japanese expressed admiration for the Peruvian raid, but wondered whether Japan, with its postwar tradition of pacifism, would have been able to do it itself. A13 Russia and China Make Pledge Presidents Jiang Zemin of China and Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia pledged to collaborate to limit American power and influence in the world. Their statement argued for a multipolar world and against any country's seeking hegemony. A3 Clinton Drops In on Dalai Lama President Clinton met informally with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader, and told him he would urge China to open a dialogue with him. The Dalai Lama, whom Beijing accuses of seeking to lead an independence movement, said Tibetans seek self-rule only. A3 Indictment Protested in Israel In a packed stadium in Jerusalem, thousands of supporters cheered Aryeh Deri, a longtime power broker facing indictment in an influence-peddling scandal. Members of the Orthodox Shas movement of Sephardic, or non-European, Jews, which Mr. Deri heads, said he was the scapegoat of a secular establishment of Jews of European descent. President Ezer Weizman cautioned Shas members not to aggravate ethnic tensions. A7 Albania Reports Gun Smuggling Albania's Justice Minister said many of the hundreds of thousands of assault rifles and other weapons looted from Government storehouses during riots last month had been smuggled into nearby Macedonia, a former Yugoslav republic with a large Albanian minority. The Macedonian authorities and United Nations officials there said that they had seen no smuggling but that it could easily be going on without their knowledge. It was not known if the rifles were staying in Macedonia or being shipped on from there. A8 Caught by the DNA of a Cat DNA drawn from cat hairs helped convict a Canadian man of murdering his estranged girlfriend, the science journal Nature reported. It is believed to be the first time that animal DNA has been introduced as evidence in a court case. A5 NATIONAL A14-27, B7-8 A 63-Year-Old Woman Gives Birth, With Help Doctors reported that a 63-year-old Southern California woman had given birth to a girl using a younger woman's donated egg. She is believed to be the oldest woman ever to have given birth. A1 Energy Goal for Refrigerators The Government ordered that all refrigerators sold in 2001 use 30 percent less electricity than those on the market today. The order ended a bitter battle over how strict new rules on refrigerators should be and when they should take effect. The rule will add $80 to the average refrigerator's price but will lower its annual operating cost by about $20. A1 Reed Quits Christian Coalition Ralph Reed announced his resignation as executive director of the Christian Coalition. He said he wanted to become involved in politics more directly than its nonprofit status allowed. He will start a campaign consulting firm; his departure is expected to be a blow to the coalition. B8 Wreckage of A-10 Confirmed Wreckage found in Colorado is from the Air Force A-10 attack jet that vanished on a training mission over Arizona three weeks ago, the military confirmed. Pieces of the wreckage were recovered by a searcher hanging from a helicopter. There was no sign of the pilot, Capt. Craig Button. A14 New Bill on Children's Health Two Senators, a Republican and a Democrat, said they would introduce legislation to expand Medicaid to cover five million uninsured children. The Senators, John H. Chafee and John D. Rockefeller 4th, did not say how they would pay for it. B8 Court to Rule on Line-Item Veto The Supreme Court granted an accelerated hearing on the line-item veto law, which a Federal judge struck down two weeks ago. It will hear arguments May 27 and should rule by early summer. B7 Clash Over 'Multiracial' Label Federal experts clashed over the wisdom of changing the way the Government categorizes people by race. Some said adding a new category for ''multiracial'' would be more accurate; others worried over its cost and its effect on bias laws. A27 Eavesdropping Pair Charged A minor criminal charge was filed against a Florida couple who said they had intercepted and recorded a conference call last December among Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republican leaders. A26 4 Accused in Bombing Plot Four people were charged with plotting to bomb a natural gas plant in Texas and kill law-enforcement officials to divert attention from armored-car robberies they also planned, the F.B.I. said. A22 Wheelchair Sought for F.D.R. The Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial in Washington should show Roosevelt in his wheelchair, President Clinton said. As of now, it does not. B8 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Youths in Pizza Killings Are Depicted as Wanton Acquaintances of the New Jersey teen-agers charged with killing two pizza deliverymen described them as heedless of the law and delighting in derring-do. Thomas Koskovich, the youth accused of instigating the crime, frequently spoke about an uncle who has spent most of his life behind bars, they said. Mr. Koskovich's grandmother said he must have been on drugs. A1 The Sussex County Prosecutor said he would seek to have the other suspect, Jay Vreeland, who is 17, tried as an adult in the killings. B4 Six Flags Over Yasgur's Farm? A wealthy businessman bought the site of the fabled 1969 Woodstock concert to turn it into a theme park and shrine to the 1960's counterculture. Officials in economically depressed Sullivan County, N.Y., welcomed the proposal. Whether the 400,000 people who camped in the mud there would agree was unclear. B1 Scholarship Program Swamped Parents of more than 17,250 public-school children applied for 1,300 scholarships to private and parochial schools that a group of Wall Street executives is offering. Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said the parents' dissatisfaction with New York City's public schools had come through loud and clear. B3 Car Insurance Cost Protested More than 500 angry drivers waving homemade signs and wearing buttons rallied at the New Jersey State House to demand that Governor Whitman and lawmakers do something to lower the highest auto insurance rates in the nation. B5 HOME C1-11 SPORTS B9-20 Zoeller Pulls Out of Tournament Fuzzy Zoeller pulled out of the Greater Greensboro Classic golf tournament and said he wanted to ''make things right'' with Tiger Woods. Zoeller said he had not talked to Woods about the racial comments he made in a television interview. His remarks led Kmart to drop Zoeller as its golf spokesman. B9 ARTS C13-20 Now in Manhattan: $9 Movies Ticket prices hit the $9 mark at one Manhattan movie theater complex, the Sony Lincoln Square multiplex on the Upper West Side. Sony raised the prices at its other 10 Manhattan houses to $8.75 from $8.50. Its rival, Cineplex Odeon, said it was in the midst of its semiannual study of ticket prices. C13 BUSINESS DAY D1-28 Business Digest D1 OBITUARIES D29 Jean Louis The Academy Award-winning designer who created some of the most memorable costumes and fashions worn by Hollywood stars of the 1940's, 50's and 60's was 89. Born Jean Louis Berthault, he was responsible for the glittering ''beads and skin'' dress worn by Marilyn Monroe for her breathless rendition of ''Happy Birthday'' to President John F. Kennedy in Madison Square Garden in 1962. D29 Henry A. Mucci A charismatic Army colonel, he became an instant and enduring American war hero in 1945 when he led the raid that rescued 500 survivors of Corregidor and the Bataan Death March from a Japanese prison camp in the Philippines. He was 88. D29 EDITORIAL A28-29 Editorials: A justifiable rescue, no ordinary disaster, protecting infant nutrition, Connecticut's war on drugs. Columns: Frank Rich, Thomas L. Friedman. Chronicle D30 Bridge C18 Crossword C18 Weather C11
